awd_titl_txt: Acoustic Field Transport in Periodic and Disordered Metamaterials: a Fractional-order Continuum Approach.
awd_abstract_narration:
Acoustic metamaterials are engineered material-structures systems (or media) that exhibit properties not readily achievable in natural materials. A prototypical metamaterial consists of an assembly of structural elements in one or more geometric shapes, sometimes characterized by a hierarchy of length scales. One purpose for which metamaterials are frequently designed for is to achieve a medium that is capable of transferring sound in remarkably unique ways that are not found naturally. When sound propagates in a solid medium it gives rise to noise and vibrations that, in the long term, are responsible for structural deterioration and potentially catastrophic failure. The complexity and multiscale nature of metamaterials poses many computational challenges that have so far limited their use in real-world applications. This award supports fundamental research to develop mathematical and computational methods that will enable the design and simulation of metamaterials. The ability to design materials capable of controlling the propagation of sound can have major implications on the ability to achieve quieter, safer, and more durable transportation systems and infrastructures in the fields of aerospace, mechanical, civil, and biomedical engineering, thereby promoting the progress of science; advancing national health, prosperity, and welfare; and securing the national defense The educational part of this project involves developing new tools and exercises to help students visualizing engineering concepts and integrating them in the academic curriculum.

This research takes full advantage of the potential and unique features of fractional calculus to develop a computational continuum mechanics framework for the analysis of acoustic field transport in metamaterials. Fractional order operators encompass a variety of non-traditional properties ranging from memory effects to non-locality, from multi-scale features to hybrid transport mechanisms that make them uniquely suited to simulate the dynamics of elastic waves in inhomogeneous media. The research will develop methodologies to synthesize fractional-order wave propagation models from fundamental principles and it will apply them to the design and performance prediction of periodic and random metamaterials. This research will develop key capabilities at both physical and mathematical level. At physical level, it will allow capturing and predicting anomalous acoustic field transport mechanisms that otherwise would be undetected. At mathematical level, it will develop methodologies to find exact or approximate analytical solutions that would transform the way inverse material-design problems are approached. The project has three main thrust areas: 1) development of the necessary theoretical background to derive fractional continuum models of inhomogeneous media from first principles, 2) application of the framework to the analysis of periodic and disordered metamaterials with particular emphasis on understanding anomalous propagation regimes, and 3) experimental validation of the theoretical and computational framework on representative acoustic metamaterials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a theoretical and computational framework, based on fractional calculus, for the analysis of acoustic and elastic wave propagation through inhomogeneous media and metamaterials. This general class of problems has significant practical implications for a variety of real-world applications including, but not limited to, the design of materials for sound control and shielding, the localization of sound sources in complex (e.g. urban or underwater) environments, the design of lightweight structures with embedded vibration control and attenuation capabilities (critical to extend the operating life of high performance structures used in aerospace applications and, more generally, in transportation systems). It is envisioned that the potential impact of this research could extend to interdisciplinary applications including the prediction of the effects of seismic waves, the propagation of light in scattering media (critical to enhance low-visibility conditions, such as in fog or murky water), and the diffusion of contaminants in porous soil. All these problems share an important common denominator: the need for a structured mathematical framework able to model and carefully predict the transport of the wave field through complex inhomogeneous and scattering media. Fractional order operators encompass a variety of non-traditional properties ranging from memory effects to non-locality, to hybrid transport mechanisms that make them uniquely suited to accurately and efficiently simulate the dynamic response of these complex material systems.

 

This project developed the theoretical foundation and the associated numerical tools to simulate the propagation of acoustic and elastic waves in inhomogeneous media and metamaterials. In addition to the many foundational results contributing to forming the backbone of fractional order mechanics, this project uncovered many important aspects and applications of fractional order models in mechanics. As an example, the new framework allows efficient homogenization techniques that lead to computationally efficient models while still maintaining detailed information of the material microstructure. The theoretical formulation allowed elucidating the complex interplay between material scales and macroscopic behavior that give rise to phenomena such as anomalous transport, unconventional plastic behavior, and material degradation, to name a few. In addition, this tool opens new and remarkable opportunities to develop the next generation of multiscale models broadly applicable in a variety of disciplines, even beyond engineering.

 

This project provided significant contributions also at educational level. While fractional calculus is an active branch of research in the mathematics community, it has started percolating into the science and engineering fields only in more recent years. Currently, most technical curricula do not include this topic so that opportunities for formal training are quite scarce. This project contributed to the development of theoretical concepts and technical manuscripts that will form the basis for the development of dedicated instructional material. It also provided opportunities to train a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students on the general area of fractional calculus and, more in general, on interdisciplinary topics combining applied mathematics, mechanics, and numerical computations. The project also offered excellent opportunities for peer-to-peer mentoring allowing students to experience firsthand the importance, as well as the complexities, of mentoring junior researchers in STEM disciplines and hopefully inspiring younger minds to pursue a career in science.
